News Flash

Alhambra City Council Advances Plans for Permanent Dog Park

At its regular meeting on June 24, 2024, the Alhambra City Council authorized staff to circulate a Request for Proposals (RFP) to provide design and specifications for a permanent dog park, and for staff to take the required steps for implementation. The future dog park installation is set to be located near the former “Paw-Pup Dog Park” pilot project area, next to the Alhambra Golf Course.“The Alhambra City Council is thrilled to see this initiative advancing,” said Mayor Sasha Renée Pérez. “Alhambra residents have long expressed their desire for a permanent dog park, particularly following the success of our pilot program. Now, we are able to make this a permanent feature for our residents and their furry friends!”In fall 2023, the City of Alhambra hosted a temporary pilot “Paw-Pup Dog Park” for two months. As part of the program, the community was invited to provide input regarding interest in a permanent dog park through a survey, which earned over 1300 responses with about 99% of participants in favor of a permanent installation in Alhambra.As next steps, staff is seeking professional engineering and design services to provide plans and specifications for the Alhambra Dog Park Project. Anticipated dog park amenities include trees, synthetic turf, walking paths, a restroom facility, secure double fencing, benches, shade structures and dog play features.Proposals for the engineering and design services RFP are due to the Parks and Recreation Department no later than 5 PM on Monday, July 22, 2024. For more information, visit the City’s website at www.cityofalhambra.org.
News
Posted on June 25, 2024

  • Housing Element

    The Housing Element is a chapter in the City’s General Plan. It is a blueprint for how the City will plan for its share of regional housing need. The Housing Element outlines the City’s goals, policies and actions for how it will meet the community’s vision regarding future housing need. The City updated and adopted other elements of the General Plan in 2019, and now it needs to update the Housing Element. Visit the Housing Element website to learn more.

    Home
    Posted on July 12, 2021

3 of 13 news items

  • Student Art Contest for Alhambra's 2027 TOR Float

    Calling all Alhambra Unified School District Elementary Students:

    Submit your art to be the inspiration for the City of Alhambra's 2027 Tournament of Roses Float!

    Criteria: 

    • Artwork must relate to the 2027 Tournament of Roses Parade theme "Welcome", which celebrates the simple joy of belonging, warmth of family either related or chosen, and love of community.
    • All mediums are welcome, for example: pencil, pen, crayons, markets, paint, and/or digital desing.

    Eligibility and Rules:

    • Open to Alhambra Unified Elementary School students attending a school in Alhambra and living in Alhambra.
    • Students must have permission from their parent/legal guardian to complete registration.
    • One entry per student. All artwork must be exclusively original and cannot incorporate anything, in whole, or in part that is owned or created by a third party.

    Submissions due: 

    5:30 P.M. on Thursday, March 5, 2026

    Please deliver your artwork in person or by mail to Alhambra City Hall, Parks and Recreation Department at 111 South First Street, Alhambra, CA 91801

    See full form submission form here.

  • New Multi-Unit Housing Smoking Ordinance In Effect

    The Alhambra City Council passed, approved, and adopted a new law regarding smoking and smoking in multi-unit housing. This new ordinance will be implemented in two-phases with Phase 1 starting January 17, 2026 and Phase 2 implemented by and after January 17, 2029.

    Visit the following website to learn more: https://www.alhambraca.gov/874/Multi-Unit-Housing-Smoking-Regulations

    News
    Posted on February 02, 2026

  • City of Alhambra to Break Ground on New Community Center

    Alhambra, CA — The City of Alhambra is pleased to announce the Alhambra Community Center Groundbreaking Ceremony on Monday, October 20, 2025. The project is made possible by $25 million in state funding, secured through the advocacy of Senator Susan Rubio and Assemblymember Mike Fong.

    “Thanks to strong support at the state level, we're turning an underutilized space into something truly meaningful,” said Mayor Katherine Lee. “We’re creating a Community Center where residents of all ages can connect, learn and thrive.”

    The future 17,000-square-foot Alhambra Community Center will serve as a dynamic hub for programs, events and community gatherings. Planned features include:

    • A variety of leisure classes for seniors, adults, teens and children
    • Meeting and conference rooms
    • Multipurpose space for fitness, arts and enrichment activities
    • An Emergency Operations Center
    • Programmable outdoor space
    • A rentable rooftop terrace with views of the San Gabriel Mountains
    • A special event area with a pre-function courtyard and caterer’s kitchen

    Construction activities are expected to begin later this fall with a completion date to be determined.

    # # #

  • Text-to-911

    Learn about the Alhambra Police Department Text-to-911 service. This service can be used by all cellular phones to help those who are deaf, hard of hearing, speech impaired, and anyone who might be unsafe if they were to be heard.

Police Press Releases

3 of 41 news items

  • School District Staff Member Arrested Following Privacy Investigation

    ALHAMBRA, Calif. — On January 22, 2026, the Alhambra Police Department was notified by personnel from the Alhambra Unified School District regarding allegations involving a staff member at Garfield Elementary School. The allegations involved the reported unauthorized recording of a female student without her knowledge. Officers promptly initiated an investigation, which led to the identification of the suspect as Christopher Ryan Ramirez, a resident of Monrovia.

    Based on the findings of the investigation, Ramirez was arrested for Penal Code 647(j)(2) – Invasion of Privacy. He was subsequently booked at the Alhambra City Jail.

    The Alhambra Police Department takes all allegations involving the safety and privacy of students seriously and works closely with School District officials to ensure a safe learning environment for all students.

    This investigation remains ongoing. Anyone with additional information is encouraged to contact the Alhambra Police Department Investigations Division at 626-570-5157.

    ###

    Media Contact: Grant Spencer, Lieutenant626-308-4817, gspencer@alhambrapd.org

    Police Press Releases
    Posted on January 22, 2026

  • Stabbing

    ALHAMBRA, Calif. — On January 6, 2026, at approximately 2:00 pm, Alhambra Police Department’s Communication Center received a call regarding a male who was stabbed in the area of Atlantic Boulevard and Spruce Street. Officers responded to the area and contacted a male subject suffering from a stab wound. The suspect is described as a Hispanic adult male wearing all black clothing. The suspect fled the area prior to officers’ arrival, and a search in the surrounding area is ongoing for the suspect.

    As a precautionary measure, a nearby school was placed on lockdown to ensure the safety of students and staff. No students, teachers, or parents were involved in the incident, and no injuries were reported at the school. The lockdown has since been lifted, and students have been released to their parents.

    The victim was transported to a local hospital for treatment and is in stable condition. This investigation is ongoing. Anyone with information regarding this incident is encouraged to contact the Alhambra Police Department.

    ###

    Media Contact: Henry Reyes, Sergeant626-308-4820, hreyes@alhambrapd.org

    Police Press Releases
    Posted on January 06, 2026

  • Law Enforcement Grant - DUI Checkpoint

    ALHAMBRA, Calif— On June 27, 2025, the Alhambra Police Department will conduct a Driving Under the Influence (DUI) checkpoint from 7 p.m. to 3 a.m. at an undisclosed location. 

    DUI checkpoint locations are determined based on data showing incidents of impaired driving-related crashes. The primary purpose of DUI checkpoints is to promote public safety by taking suspected impaired drivers off the road.

    “Impaired drivers put others on the road at significant risk,” Traffic Officer Covarrubias said. “Any prevention measures that reduce the number of impaired drivers on our roads significantly improve traffic safety.”

    Alhambra Police Department reminds the public that impaired driving is not just from alcohol. Some prescription medications and over-the-counter drugs may interfere with driving. While medicinal and recreational marijuana are legal, driving under the influence of marijuana is illegal.

    Drivers charged with a first-time DUI face an average of $13,500 in fines and penalties, as well as a suspended license.

    Funding for this program was provided by a grant from the California Office of Traffic Safety, through the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration.

    ###

    Media Contact: Henry Reyes, Sergeant626-308-4820, hreyes@alhambrapd.org
